浥湴猠灲潶楤敤⁵湤敲⁲敧畬慴楯渠刱ⰼ⽵氾ഊ㱵氾♮扳瀻⡢⤦湢獰㭣潰楥猠潦⁡汬⁮潴楦楣慴楯湳⁯映摥捩獩潮猠浡摥⁵湤敲⁲敧畬慴楯渠串⁯爠丵ⰼ⽵氾ഊ㱵氾♮扳瀻⡣⤦湢獰㭣潰楥猠潦⁡汬⁳瑡瑥浥湴猠慮搠獴慴畴潲礠摥捬慲慴楯湳⁰牯癩摥搠畮摥爠牥杵污瑩潮⁃㄰Ⱐ慮搼⽵氾ഊ㱵氾♮扳瀻⡤⤦湢獰㭳畣栠潴桥爠摯捵浥湴猠慮搠楮景牭慴楯渠慳⁴桥⁡摭楮楳瑥物湧⁡畴桯物瑹⁭慹⁲敡獯湡扬礠牥煵楲攠景爠瑨攠灵牰潳敳⁯映摩獣桡牧楮朠瑨敩爠晵湣瑩潮猠畮摥爠瑨敳攠剥杵污瑩潮献㰯畬㸍਼扲㸦湢獰㬦湢獰㬦湢獰㬦湢獰㬨㈩♮扳瀻♮扳瀻䄠獣桥摵汥搠扯摹⁷桯⁡牥⁮潴⁡渠慤浩湩獴敲楮朠慵瑨潲楴礦⌱㔱㬼畬㸦湢獰㬨愩♮扳瀻潮⁲散敩癩湧⁦牯洠愠灥湳楯湡扬攠敭灬潹敥⁮潴楣攠潦⁨楳⁩湴敮摥搠牥瑩牥浥湴Ⱐ潲㰯畬㸍਼畬㸦湢獰㬨戩♮扳瀻潮⁧楶楮朠慮⁥浰汯祥攠湯瑩捥⁴漠瑥牭楮慴攠桩猠敭灬潹浥湴⁩渠捩牣畭獴慮捥猠楮⁷桩捨⁨攠浡礠扥捯浥⁥湴楴汥搠瑯⁡⁲整畲渠潦⁣潮瑲楢畴楯湳⁯爠瑯⁡⁢敮敦楴⁰慹慢汥⁯畴⁯映瑨攠慰灲潰物慴攠獵灥牡湮畡瑩潮⁦畮搬⁯爼⽵氾ഊ㱵氾♮扳瀻⡣⤦湢獰㭯渠扥捯浩湧⁡睡牥⁯映慮礠潴桥爠捩牣畭獴慮捥猠睨楣栠浡礠湥捥獳楴慴攠慮礠灡祭敮琠潵琠潦⁴桡琠晵湤ⰼ⽵氾慲攠瑯⁣潭灬礬⁡猠獯潮⁡猠楳⁲敡獯湡扬礠灲慣瑩捡扬攬⁷楴栠瑨攠牥煵楲敭敮瑳⁩渠灡牡杲慰栠⠳⤮㱢爾㱢爾♮扳瀻♮扳瀻♮扳瀻♮扳瀻⠳⤦湢獰㬦湢獰㭔桥⁲敱畩牥浥湴猠浥湴楯湥搠楮⁰慲慧牡灨 ㈩⁡牥⁴漠楮景牭⁴桥⁡灰牯灲楡瑥⁡摭楮楳瑥物湧⁡畴桯物瑹⁯映瑨攠湯瑩捥⁯爠潴桥爠捩牣畭獴慮捥猠慮搦⌱㔱㬼畬㸦湢獰㬨愩♮扳瀻獥湤⁴桥洠灡牴楣畬慲猠潦⁴桥⁥浰汯祥攧猠牥浵湥牡瑩潮⁤畲楮朠瑨攠灥物潤⁴桡琠楳⁲敬敶慮琠瑯⁡⁤散楳楯渠潮⁴桥⁡浯畮琠潦⁴桥⁢敮敦楴⁴桡琠浡礠扥捯浥⁰慹慢汥⁴漠潲⁩渠牥獰散琠潦⁨業Ⱐ慮搼⽵氾ഊ㱵氾♮扳瀻⡢⤦湢獰㭳敮搠瑨敭⁡⁣潰礠潦⁡湹⁲敬敶慮琠浥摩捡氠潲⁤敡瑨⁣敲瑩晩捡瑥⁡湤⁯映慮礠捥牴楦楣慴攠楳獵敤⁢礠瑨攠扯摹⁵湤敲⁲敧畬慴楯渠䔲㐮㰯畬㸍਼扲㸦湢獰㬦湢獰㬦湢獰㬦湢獰㬨㐩♮扳瀻♮扳瀻䅮⁡摭楮楳瑥物湧⁡畴桯物瑹⁷桥渠湯瑩晹楮朠愠灥牳潮⁷桯⁩猠湯琠楮⁴桥楲⁥浰汯祭敮琠潦⁡⁤散楳楯渠畮摥爠牥杵污瑩潮⁎㌠潲⁎㐠慲攠瑯⁳敮搠愠捯灹⁯映瑨攠湯瑩晩捡瑩潮⁴漠瑨攠扯摹Ⱐ楦⁡湹Ⱐ睨漠慲攠瑨攠敭灬潹楮朠慵瑨潲楴礠楮⁲敬慴楯渠瑯⁴桡琠灥牳潮⸼扲㸼扲㸦湢獰㬦湢獰㬦湢獰㬦湢獰㬨㔩♮扳瀻♮扳瀻䥦⁡渠慤浩湩獴敲楮朠慵瑨潲楴礠摥捩摥Ⱐ潲⁴桥⁓散牥瑡特⁯映却慴攠摥瑥牭楮敳⁵湤敲⁲敧畬慴楯渠丸Ⱐ瑨慴⁴桥⁣潮摩瑩潮猠獰散楦楥搠楮⁲敧畬慴楯渠䘳⠲⤠瑯 㤩⁡牥⁳慴楳晩敤⁩渠牥污瑩潮⁴漠愠灥牳潮Ⱐ慮搠牥杵污瑩潮⁆㌨㈩⡦⤠慰灬楥猠慮搠瑨攠獣桥浥⁤敳楧湡瑥搠畮摥爠牥杵污瑩潮⁆㔨㈩⡢⤠楳⁮潴⁡⁳捨敭攠獰散楦楥搠楮⁓捨敤畬攠ㄵⰠ瑨攠慵瑨潲楴礠獨慬氠慳⁳潯渠慳⁩猠牥慳潮慢汹⁰牡捴楣慢汥☣ㄵㄻ㱵氾♮扳瀻⡡⤦湢獰㭩湦潲洠瑨攠獣桥浥⁭慮慧敲猠潦⁴桥⁤敳楧湡瑥搠獣桥浥⁴桡琠潮⁲散敩灴⁢礠瑨攠慵瑨潲楴礠潦⁡⁴牡湳晥爠癡汵攠⡣慬捵污瑥搠楮⁡捣潲摡湣攠睩瑨⁐慲琠嘠潦⁓捨敤畬攠ㄶ⤠牥杵污瑩潮⁆㘨ㄩ 牥捫潮慢汥⁳敲癩捥⁡湤⁢敮敦楴猠楮⁲敳灥捴⁯映睡爠獥牶楣攩⁷潵汤⁡灰汹⁴漠瑨攠灥牳潮Ⱐ慮搼⽵氾ഊ㱵氾♮扳瀻⡢⤦湢獰㭩湦潲洠瑨敭⁯映瑨攠牡瑥⁯爠慭潵湴Ⱐ慳⁴桥⁣慳攠浡礠扥Ⱐ瑯⁢攠畳敤⁩渠慳捥牴慩湩湧⁃⁯映瑨攠景牭畬愠獥琠潵琠楮⁴桡琠偡牴⸼⽵氾ഊ㱢爾ഊ㰯畬㸍਼愠湡浥㴢浤楶刴∾㰯愾ഊ㱵氾ഊ㱢㹐牯癩獩潮猠慳⁴漠捯湴物扵瑩潮猠敱畩癡汥湴⁰牥浩畭猼⽢㸼扲㸦湢獰㬦湢獰㬦湢獰㬦湢獰㬼戾刴⸼⽢㸦⌱㔱㬨ㄩ♮扳瀻♮扳瀻坨敲攠愠獣桥摵汥搠扯摹⁰慹⁡⁣潮瑲楢畴楯湳⁥煵楶慬敮琠灲敭極洠畮摥爠偡牴⁉䥉⁯映瑨攠健湳楯湳⁁捴⁩渠牥獰散琠潦⁡湹⁰敮獩潮慢汥⁥浰汯祥攬⁴桥礠慲攠敮瑩瑬敤⁴漠牥捯癥爬⁯爠楦⁴桥礠慲攠慮⁡摭楮楳瑥物湧⁡畴桯物瑹⁴漠牥瑡楮Ⱐ潵琠潦⁴桥⁡灰牯灲楡瑥⁳異敲慮湵慴楯渠晵湤⁡⁳畭⁮潴⁥硣敥摩湧⁴桥⁡浯畮琠潦⁴桡琠灲敭極洬⁬敳猠瑨攠慭潵湴 楦⁡湹⤠睨楣栠瑨敹⁣潵汤⁲散潶敲⁯爠牥瑡楮⁵湤敲⁳散瑩潮‴㜠潦⁴桡琠䅣琠楮⁲敳灥捴⁯映瑨攠灲敭極洮㱢爾㱢爾♮扳瀻♮扳瀻♮扳瀻♮扳瀻⠲⤦湢獰㬦湢獰㭗桥牥⁳畣栠愠捯湴物扵瑩潮猠敱畩癡汥湴⁰牥浩畭⁩猠牥晵湤敤⁵湤敲⁲敧畬慴楯渠㠨㌩⡣⤠潦⁴桥⁏捣異慴楯湡氠健湳楯渠卣桥浥猠⡃潮瑲慣瑩湧ⵯ畴⤠剥杵污瑩潮猠ㄹ㠴㱳異㸼愠湡浥㴢普昰㜰∾㰯愾㱡⁨牥昽∣瑦湦〷〢㹛㜰崼⽡㸼⽳異㸬⁴桥⁡畴桯物瑹⁴漠睨潭⁩琠楳⁲敦畮摥搠獨慬氠灡礠瑯⁴桥⁳異敲慮湵慴楯渠晵湤⁴漠睨楣栠瑨攠灥牳潮⁩湶潬癥搠桡猠扥捯浥⁡⁣潮瑲楢畴潲⁡⁳畭⁥煵慬⁴漠瑨攠慭潵湴⁯映瑨攠灲敭極洮㱢爾ഊ㰯畬㸍਼⽰㸍਼扲㸍਼桲㸍਼椾乯瑥猺㰯椾㱢爾㱢爾ഊ㱰㸍਼愠湡浥㴢瑦湦〶㠢㹛㘸崠㰯愾匮䤮☣ㄶ〻㱡㸱㤵㐯ㄲ㐳㰯愾㱡⁨牥昽∣普昰㘸∾⁢慣欼⽡㸍਼⽰㸍਼瀾ഊ㱡⁮慭攽≴普昰㘹∾嬶㥝‼⽡㹓⹒⸦⌱㘰㬦慭瀻⁏⸠㱡㸱㤳㠯㈴㔼⽡㸼愠桲敦㴢⍦湦〶㤢㸠扡捫㰯愾ഊ㰯瀾ഊ㱰㸍਼愠湡浥㴢瑦湦〷〢㹛㜰崠㰯愾匮䤮☣ㄶ〻㱡㸱㤸㐯㌸〼⽡㸬⁴漠睨楣栠瑨敲攠慲攠慭敮摭敮瑳⁮潴⁲敬敶慮琠瑯⁴桥獥⁒敧畬慴楯湳⸼愠桲敦㴢⍦湦〷〢㸠扡捫㰯愾ഊ㰯瀾㰯瑤㸼瑤⁷楤瑨㴢㄰┢㸦湢獰㬼⽴搾㰯瑲㸼⽴慢汥㸼瑡扬攠睩摴栽∹㔥∾ഊ㱴扯摹㸍਼瑲㸍਼瑤⁣潬獰慮㴢㌢㸍਼愠桲敦㴢啫獩弱㤸㜱㠵た敮弱㠮桴浬∾㱩浧⁳牣㴢⸮⼮ⸯ業术湡瘭捯湵⹧楦∠慬楧渽≴潰∠慬琽≣潮瑩湵攢⁢潲摥爽∰∾㰯愾㱡⁮慭攽≥湤∾㰯愾㱡⁨牥昽≕歳楟ㄹ㠷ㄸ㔰彥湟ㄶ⹨瑭氢㸼業朠慬楧渽≴潰∠慬琽≰牥癩潵猠獥捴楯渢⁢潲摥爽∰∠獲挽∮ⸯ⸮⽩浧⽮慶灲敶㈮杩昢㸼⽡㸼愠桲敦㴢啫獩弱㤸㜱㠵た敮弱⹨瑭氣瑣潮∾㱩浧⁡汩杮㴢瑯瀢⁡汴㴢捯湴敮瑳∠扯牤敲㴢〢⁳牣㴢⸮⼮ⸯ業术湡瘭捯湴⹧楦∾㰯愾ഊ㱨爾ഊ㰯瑤㸍਼⽴爾ഊ㱴爾ഊ㱴搠捯汳灡渽∳∾ഊ㱡⁨牥昽∮ⸯ⸮⽳瑡琮桴浬∾佴桥爠啋⁓䥳㰯愾♮扳瀻簦湢獰㬼愠桲敦㴢⸮⼮ⸯ楮摥砮桴浬∾䡯浥㰯愾♮扳瀻簦湢獰㬼愠桲敦㴢桴瑰㨯⽷睷⹷慬敳⵬敧楳污瑩潮⹨浳漮杯瘮畫⽬敧楳污瑩潮⽷慬敳⽷⵳瑡琮桴洢㹎慴楯湡氠䅳獥浢汹⁦潲⁗慬敳⁓瑡瑵瑯特⁉湳瑲畭敮瑳㰯愾♮扳瀻簦湢獰㬼愠桲敦㴢桴瑰㨯⽷睷⹳捯瑬慮搭汥杩獬慴楯渮桭獯⹧潶⹵欯汥杩獬慴楯港獣潴污湤⽳⵳瑡琮桴洢㹓捯瑴楳栠却慴畴潲礠䥮獴牵浥湴猼⽡㸦湢獰㭼♮扳瀻㱡⁨牥昽≨瑴瀺⼯睷眮湯牴桥牮楲敬慮搭汥杩獬慴楯渮桭獯⹧潶⹵欯汥杩獬慴楯港湯牴桥牮楲敬慮搯湩⵳牮椮桴洢㹓瑡瑵瑯特⁒畬敳⁯映乯牴桥牮⁉牥污湤㰯愾♮扳瀻簦湢獰㬼愠桲敦㴢桴瑰㨯⽷睷⹨浳漮杯瘮畫⼢㹈敲⁍慪敳瑹❳⁓瑡瑩潮敲礠佦晩捥㰯愾ഊ㰯瑤㸍਼⽴爾ഊ㱴爾ഊ㱴搠捯汳灡渽∳∾ഊ㱨爾ഊ㰯瑤㸍਼⽴爾ഊ㱴爾ഊ㱴搠癡汩杮㴢瑯瀢⁷楤瑨㴢㐵┢㸍਼瀾㰯瀾ഊ㱡摤牥獳㸍਼戾㱦潮琠獩穥㴢ⴱ∾坥⁷敬捯浥⁹潵爠㱡⁨牥昽∯桭獯景牭⹨瑭∾捯浭敮瑳㰯愾⁯渠瑨楳⁳楴攼⽦潮琾㰯戾ഊ㰯慤摲敳猾ഊ㰯瑤㸍਼瑤⁶慬楧渽≴潰∠睩摴栽∳〥∾ഊ㱦潮琠獩穥㴢ⴱ∾♣潰礻⁃牯睮⁣潰祲楧桴‱㤸㜼⽦潮琾ഊ㰯瑤㸍਼瑤⁡汩杮㴢物杨琢⁷楤瑨㴢㈵┢㸍਼慤摲敳猾ഊ㱦潮琠獩穥㴢ⴱ∾偲数慲敤′ぴ栠卥灴敭扥爠㈰〰㰯景湴㸍਼⽡摤牥獳㸍਼⽴搾ഊ㰯瑲㸍਼⽴扯摹㸍਼⽴慢汥㸼⽤楶㸼⽢潤社ഊ㰡ⴭ⁧慴桥牥搠睩瑨⁰敲浩獳楯渠批⁵歷慣⁦牯洠睷眮潰獩⹧潶⹵欯獩⽳椱㤸㜯啫獩弱㤸㜱㠵た敮弱㜮桴洠慴⁔桵Ⱐㄳ⁁灲′〰㘠㄰㨴㐺ㄱ⁇䵔‭ⴾഊ㰯桴浬�

	Title:	Challenges to establishing markets for watershed services: Learning from country diagnostics
	Author:	Tighe Geoghegan
	Published:	Jul 2005 - IIED
	Area of work:	Forestry and Land Use
	Areas:	India, Indonesia, South Africa, Grenada, St Lucia, Jamaica, Trinidad&Tobabgo
	Topics:	Forestry,  Natural Resources,  Water
	Details:	28 pages
	Language:	English
	Product Code:	13520IIED
	Price:	FREE,  FREE for Non-OECD countries,  FREE for students
FREE,  FREE for Non-OECD countries,  FREE for students
	Status:	Free download (PDF)
	Abstract:	This paper synthesises a set of diagnostic studies carried out by the International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED) and local partners in 2001-2002 to explore the potential of market-based approaches for watershed protection. The studies responded to concerns raised in earlier work by IIED that markets for watershed services were being promoted without adequate consideration of their costs and benefits. Studies carried out for four countries or regions – the Caribbean, India, Indonesia and South Africa – included an assessment of key watershed management issues and needs; potential market actors; the policy and institutional context; and interest in and demand for market-based approaches.

Arts Council England, Yorkshire
Peter Jenkinson to step down as national director of Creative Partnerships
Date:	18th Feb 2004


Peter Jenkinson OBE is to step down as National Director of the Arts Council's Creative Partnerships programme at the end of March. 

Peter has led Creative Partnerships since September 2001 and has steered the project, which links young people in schools with the professional cultural and creative sectors, through its early pilot stages.  



Peter Hewitt, Arts Council England Chief Executive, said:



'Peter Jenkinson has brought vision, flair, persuasiveness, energy, intellectual authority and a powerful sense of conviction to his role as National Director of Creative Partnerships. In deciding to move to other challenges, Peter leaves behind him a legacy of having made a seminal contribution to creativity and learning for young people. I think we'll all be looking forward to his next big project.'



Tessa Jowell, Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport, added:



'Projects as ambitious and complex as Creative Partnerships are made or broken in their first couple of years - preparation is all.  Peter Jenkinson has made Creative Partnerships work, has made a reality of the theory and he deserves all our thanks for that.'



Peter Jenkinson said:



'As founding National Director of Creative Partnerships it has been my great privilege to be involved in setting up a programme that is having such a profound impact on the lives and aspirations of young people and equally of the cultural and creative partners involved.  I am confident that Creative Partnerships will continue to go from strength to strength.'

Notes for editors: 
About Creative Partnerships

Creative Partnerships provides school children across England with the opportunity to develop creativity in learning and to take part in cultural activities of the highest quality. The idea behind Creative Partnerships is a simple one – to animate teaching and learning and to enrich school life by making best use of the UK's creative wealth. Based at Arts Council England, Creative Partnerships has an unique approach to working with schools. It first helps schools to identify their individual needs and then enables them to develop long-term, sustainable partnerships with organisations and individuals from the cultural and creative sectors including architects, theatre companies, museums, cinemas, historic buildings, dance studios, recording studios, orchestras, film-makers, web-site designers and many others. 



Currently there are over 1,600 projects under way in schools involving 1,500 creative and cultural organisations and individuals.  Students have been involved in nearly 4 million hours of Creative Partnerships activity.



For its first two years' work (April 2002 – March 2004), it received £40 million from the Department for Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS), working closely with the Department for Education and Skills (DfES).  In June 2003, the DCMS and the DfES confirmed a further £70 million investment for 20 new Creative Partnerships areas – in addition to the 16 currently running – to be created by 2006.



www.creative-partnerships.com



Further information from:

David McNeill, Director of Press and Public Affairs on 020 7973 6458 or 07884 311034 (mobile)

title: Defra, UK; Rural Affairs - Rural Evidence Base
text:
Defra, UK; Rural Affairs - Rural Evidence Base
Skip navigation

	
			
      Rural Affairs

    	
	Home | Contact Defra | About Defra | News | Access to information | Links | Search | Site A-Z
	



	



	
		Homepage > Rural Affairs > Rural Evidence Base > Social Impacts ... 
	
			
      The Wider Social Impacts of Changes in the Structure of Agricultural Businesses 

    
	
		 
      	Rural Affairs homepage
	
	Rural Evidence Base
	
		Social Impacts..
	
	Related sites
	
	Economics and Statistics
	
	Science
	
	Wildlife & Countryside Research papers


    		
      Background

      In the light of reforms to the Common Agricultural Policy, Defra commissioned The University of Exeter to examine the current and likely future restructuring of England’s agricultural businesses and to consider the wider social implications of these changes.  A total of 115 interviews were conducted (35 non-farmers and 80 farmers) in six study areas in England.  By comparing responses from the current survey to those recorded for the same farms in 2001/02 the researchers were able to explore the restructuring trends and the nature of associated social implications.

      The results of the survey suggest the following key findings

      	a consolidation of existing restructuring trends
	few farmers appear to be planning to leave the industry in the next five years
	farmers identified as "active adaptors" tend to be younger, highly educated and operate large farm business often alongside other business interests
	those who have actively restructured their business, and frequently stepped off the agricultural treadmill, identified benefits in terms of reduced stress, more time for family activities and the opportunity to get away from the farm
	in general, farmers are less socially active than non-farmers
	amongst the farming population, "active adaptors" are more likely to be involved in community based organisations
	non-farmers were more likely than farmers to think that farmers played an economically and socially important role in the community.

This includes reproduction of the Statutory Rule on the Internet and on intranet sites.  The Royal Arms may be reproduced only where they are an integral part of the original document.





The text of this Internet version of the Statutory Rule which is published by the Government Printer for Northern Ireland has been prepared to reflect the text as it was Made. A print version is also available and is published by The Stationery Office Limited as the Seed Potatoes (Crop Fees) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2000 , ISBN 0 33 793886 5.  The print version may be purchased by clicking  here. Braille copies of this Statutory Rule can also be purchased at the same price as the print edition by contacting TSO Customer Services on 0870 600 5522 or e-mail:customer.services@tso.co.uk.




Further information about the publication of legislation on this website can be found by referring to the Frequently Asked Questions. 


To ensure fast access over slow connections, large documents have been segmented into "chunks". Where you see a "continue" button at the bottom of the page of text, this indicates that there is another chunk of text available.







STATUTORY RULES OF NORTHERN IRELAND



2000 No. 138


AGRICULTURE


Seed Potatoes (Crop Fees) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2000

	 	
Made	21st April 2000	 
	 	
Coming into operation	29th May 2000	 




The Department of Agriculture and Rural Development[1], in exercise of its powers conferred on it by section 1 of the Seeds Act (Northern Ireland) 1965[2] and of all powers enabling it in that behalf, after consultation with representatives of such interests as appear to it to be concerned, hereby makes the following Regulations:



Citation, commencement and interpretation

    

1.
 - (1) These Regulations may be cited as the Seed Potatoes (Crop Fees) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2000 and shall come into operation on 29th May 2000.


    (2) In these Regulations, "the Department" means the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development.



Fees

    

2.
Every person who makes an application to the Department for the certification of seed potato crops under regulation 5(1) of the Seed Potatoes Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1981[3] shall forward with that application the appropriate fee in accordance with the Schedule.



Revocation

    

3.
The Seed Potatoes (Crop Fees) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1999[4] are hereby revoked.





Sealed with the Official Seal of the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development on 21st April 2000.


L.S.

R. S. Johnston

Senior Officer of the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development






SCHEDULERegulation 2





Fees for the certification of seed potato crops



	

Application
	

Fee

	

    
1.
In the case of an application received by the Department on or before 30th May in any calendar year - 




(a) where the total area of the crop does not exceed 1 hectare


	
£33·00
	
(b) where the total area of the crop exceeds 1 hectare


	
£16·50 per half hectare or part of a half hectare
	

    
2.
In the case of an application received by the Department after 30th May in any calendar year - 




(a) where the total area of the crop does not exceed 1 hectare


	
£49·50
	
(b) where the total area of the crop exceeds 1 hectare


	
£24·75 per half hectare or part of a half hectare







EXPLANATORY NOTE



(This note is not part of the Regulations.)


These Regulations increase the fees payable to the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development in respect of the certification of seed potato crops arising under the Seed Potatoes Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1981 (regulation 2 and the Schedule).


In the case of an application received by the Department on or before 30th May in any calendar year: - 




(a) where the total area of the crop does not exceed 1 hectare the fee is increased from £32·00 to £33·00;


(b) where the total area of the crop exceeds 1 hectare the fee is increased from £16·00 to £16·50 per half hectare or part of a half hectare.



In the case of an application received by the Department after 30th May in any calendar year: - 





(a) where the total area of the crop does not exceed 1 hectare the fee is increased from £48·00 to £49·50;


(b) where the total area of the crop exceeds 1 hectare the fee is increased from £24·00 to £24·75 per half hectare or part of a half hectare.



The Regulations also revoke the Seed Potatoes (Crop Fees) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1999 (regulation 3).




Notes:



[1] 
Formerly the Department of Agriculture for Northern Ireland. See Article 3(4) of the Departments (Northern Ireland) Order 1999 (S.I. 1999/283 (N.I.))back

1965 c. 22 (N.I.) as amended by S.R. & O. (N.I.) 1972 No. 351 Art. 3 and Sch. 3back


[3] 
S.R. 1981 No. 243 as amended by S.R. 1983 No. 244, S.R. 1985 No. 2, S.R. 1991 No. 397, S.R. 1993 No. 372, S.R. 1994 No. 459 and S.R. 1999 No. 185back


[4] 
S.R. 1999 No. 185back
